metadata.titleEn: Fossil Records of Palms of the Lunpola Basin, central Tibetan Plateau (2019)
metadata.description: This dataset is derived from the paper: Su, T. et al. (2019). No high tibetan plateau until the Neogene. Science Advances, 5(3), eaav2189. doi:10.1126/sciadv.aav2189 This data contains supplementary material of this article. Researchers discovered well-preserved palm fossil leaves from the Lunpola Basin (32.033°N, 89.767°E), central Tibetan Plateau at a present elevation of 4655 m in 2016. Researchers compared the newly discovered fossil with those present fossil that are most similar, find that there is no similar leaves among present fossil, therefore, researchers proposed the new species S. tibetensis T. Su et Z.K. Zhou sp. nov. Using the climate model, combined with the research of the fossil, researchers rebuilt the paleoelevation of the central Tibetan Plateau, it shows that a high plateau cannot have existed in the core of Tibet in the Paleogene. The data contains the following tables: 1) Table S1. Fossil records of palms around the world. 2) Table S2. Morphological comparisons between fossils from Lunpola Basin and modern palm genera. 3) Table S3. Climate ranges of 12 living genera that show the closest morphological similarity to S. tibetensis T. Su et Z.K. Zhou sp. nov. This dataset also contains the figures in the supplementary material in the article.
metadata.instructions: The data is stored in table format，it can be viewed and edited by Excel software of Microsoft Office

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a data collection method used to gather fossil records of palms and how it was applied to reconstruct paleoelevation in the Tibetan Plateau?
Example.Answer: A research approach involved discovering well-preserved palm fossils in the Lunpola Basin, central Tibetan Plateau. Researchers used these fossils, combined with paleoclimate models, to reconstruct the paleoelevation of the region, concluding that the high Tibetan Plateau did not exist before the Neogene.

Quantification.Question: How many tables are included in a dataset related to palm fossil records from the Lunpola Basin and their morphological comparisons?

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors have contributed to the development of methodologies for collecting and comparing palm fossil records in central Tibetan Plateau regions?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The discovery of well-preserved palm fossils in the central Tibetan Plateau, particularly in the Lunpola Basin, necessitated the development of methodologies that could accurately collect and compare these fossils with existing records. The need to establish a new species, Sabalites tibensis, due to its distinct morphology compared to existing palm fossils, also led to the development of specific data collection techniques. Additionally, the integration of palm fossil data with paleoclimate models to reconstruct paleoaltitudes of the Tibetan Plateau before the Neogene period further influenced the data collection methods employed.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the primary goal of collecting and analyzing palm fossil records in the Lunpola Basin area of the central Tibetan Plateau?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The primary goal of collecting and analyzing palm fossil records in the Lunpola Basin area is to reconstruct the paleoelevation of the central Tibetan Plateau during the Neogene period by using palm fossils, which provide clues about past climate conditions and environmental settings. This helps to conclude that the high Tibetan Plateau did not exist until the Neogene.
